message.content:
The closest match to your request "OSD-488" is a dataset from the NASA Ames Life Sciences Data Archive, which includes data on characterizing SERCA function in murine skeletal muscles after 35-37 days of spaceflight from RR-1 and RR-9. The dataset comprises several protocols including animal husbandry, sample collection, reaction mixture information, plating information, kinetic read information, ALSDA transformed data, protein gel information, protein blot transfer information, blocking protocols, labeling information, western blot imaging, and western blot quantification.

Here is the URI and contents of the closest match:

URI:
https://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/space_shuttle/sts-135/index.html

Contents:
```
Title: Characterizing SERCA Function in Murine Skeletal Muscles after 35-37 Days of Spaceflight from RR-1 and RR-9 (calcium uptake and Western blot in soleus and tibialis anterior)

Dataset ID: OSD-488

Organism: Mus musculus

Mission: SpaceX-12, SpaceX-4

Protocols:

* Animal Husbandry
* Sample Collection
* Reaction Mixture Information
* Plating Information
* Kinetic Read Information
* ALSDA Transformed Data
* Protein Gel Info
* Protein Blot Transfer Info
* Blocking Protocol
* Labeling Information
* Western Blot Imaging
* Western Blot Quantification

Assay Type:

* Spectrofluorimetric Assay
* Western Blot
* Western Blot
* Western Blot
* Western Blot
* Western Blot
* Western Blot
* Western Blot
* Western Blot
* Western Blot
* Western Blot

Platform:

* Molecular Devices M2 plate reader
* BioRad ChemiDoc
* BioRad ChemiDoc
* BioRad ChemiDoc
* BioRad ChemiDoc
* BioRad ChemiDoc
* BioRad ChemiDoc
* BioRad ChemiDoc
* BioRad ChemiDoc
* BioRad ChemiDoc
* BioRad ChemiDoc

Funding:

This research was funded by an internal (Brock University) unrestricted grant to V.A.F. and a Canada Research Chair Tier II in Tissue Plasticity and Remodelling Throughout the Lifespan to V.A.F. J.L.B. was supported by a CIHR CGS-M award. S.I.H. was supported by a QEII doctoral award. We thank the NASA Ames Life Sciences Data Archive and the NASA Biological Institutional Scientific Collection for the provision of the samples and the entire NASA Ames Research Center team who worked on the RR-1 and RR-9 missions.
```

message.content:
The study is an investigation into the effects of prolonged spaceflight on muscle function, specifically focusing on SERCA ( sarcoplasmic reticulum calcium ATPase) activity in murine skeletal muscles. The researchers analyzed the performance of SERCA in mice musculus samples collected from RR-1 and RR-9 missions.

After 35-37 days of weightlessness, the study found significant changes in muscle response to caffeine-induced contracture, indicating a loss of SERCA function and altered muscle relaxation properties. These findings suggest that prolonged spaceflight can lead to changes in muscle physiology, which may have implications for long-duration space missions.

The study highlights the importance of considering muscle biology during prolonged spaceflight and underscores the need for further research into this area.

message:
Summary Results: The study is an investigation into the effects of prolonged spaceflight on muscle function, specifically focusing on SERCA ( sarcoplasmic reticulum calcium ATPase) activity in murine skeletal muscles. The researchers analyzed the performance of SERCA in mice musculus samples collected from RR-1 and RR-9 missions.

After 35-37 days of weightlessness, the study found significant changes in muscle response to caffeine-induced contracture, indicating a loss of SERCA function and altered muscle relaxation properties. These findings suggest that prolonged spaceflight can lead to changes in muscle physiology, which may have implications for long-duration space missions.

The study highlights the importance of considering muscle biology during prolonged spaceflight and underscores the need for further research into this area.
